column2: saved, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was intubated twice (with in a month) about 2 years ago at the age of 28.  I was starting to accept the fact that I was going to die from my asthma. I was on every medication that exists for asthma and I still had to prepare my breathing machine before bed. They came on so quickly and so hard that I couldn't even tear open my meds. Finally, I had a doctor test my IgE levels and suggest Xolair.  My doctor thankfully fought the insurance company and I got the approval.  I am so blessed to be on this medication.  I am able to exercise once again, I haven't taken a breathing treatment in 2 years, and I rarely use my rescue inhaler. Xolair has saved my life and my kids don't have to watch me suffer through hours of laying on the floor trying to breathe. Not to mention I have not had a single negative side effect.

column9: I have had asthma for most of my life, but it was easily controlled until 2 years ago.  Since early 2009 I have been on steroids either monthly or daily in order to minimize my asthma symptoms.  I have been on Xolair for almost 1 year.  I still need my other medications including prednisone; however, I have been able to reduce the dosage of prednisone significantly.  It has not been a miracle drug for me, but Xolair has definitely reduced my asthma attacks and my daily symptoms.  I have had no significant side effects and would recommend the drug to anyone with severe asthma.

column2: IBITETTI, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Was diagnosed with asthma & allergies over 20 years ago. I think I have tried just about every asthma/allergy medicine available on the market. My first inhaler sent me to the emergency room with anaphylaxis. I have gotten increasingly worse over the years, and it got to the point where I was afraid that nothing would help.I have no medical insurance , so the cost of the xolair is bery high...but who cares...it changed my life totally within two hours of the injection.I am "alive" for the first time in a very long time.I was coughing non stop until I coughed up bile/blood and every muscle in my body ached all the time. the last four years I have taken Cipro for my bronchitis and Cortisone to be able to open up my airways.I lost my sence of smelling in my twenties and have had numerous polyp operations in my sinuses.I would be on meds for up to 20 days,getting a little relief, and one week after the last pill it was back to the same sleepless nights with the coughing & sweating.I would wait as long as I could before starting a new round of meds, and my last asthma attack did not go away even with higher doses of cortisone.I was told that my last resort was xolair as nothing else helped, so I was a little nervous when I went for my first shot.What if it did not help?Wow, I've never been happier??? I coughed up some mucus that was trapped about an hour after the treatment, and have not been coughing since. And moreover, I got my sence of smelling back and it's just like coming from a "dead" world back to life.I'm alive!!!!!!!!& I can breathe.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: Hattie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have had severe asthma and allergies all my life (41 years). I started Xolair in July 2005. At that time I carried around my nebulizer, was taking Singulair, steroid inhalers and prednisone pretty frguently.  Within the first year, I was done with the nebulizer. I did start regular allergy immunotherapy injections in 2007. Allergies (runny nose, cold type symptoms, itchy eyes, etc.) are progressively getting better.  I hate to admit I am noncompliant, but the only asthma meds I take now are OCCASIONAL use of Asmanex. No albuterol type, cannot remember last prednisone, and no idea where my nebulizer is!   Dosing is set by the med guidelines. It has to do with your IgE levels. I take 2 (300) shots every two weeks. If I go longer -about 18 days, the asthma starts in again. I bet that if I used the Asmanex more regularly this would not happen.My only complaint is I have to drive 30 miles each way to get my shots. Overall, the drive is worth it. Xolair is the best!

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment

column9: I took my first injection this Wednesday. Within 24 hours, my nose swelling decreased significantly. I am still taking all my asthma and allergy drugs as advised (Singulair, Symbicort - maximum dose, Flonase, Zyrtec). Since I have severe pollen induced Asthma, especially from ragweed, I was doubtful that Xolair could help me. Plus, my allergist said it will take 4 to 5 months to step down from all my other asthma drugs. I am already feeling so much better that I am very surprised. Thank you, Genentech people! I can yawn again and may actually be able to sit ony deck or porchagain. Am hoping for an almost normal life soon!!!

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: twirler, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My husband has suffered from asthma since he was 6 years old (he is now 62).  From his 20s through his 40s he was symptom free, but then his asthma hit him hard and has continued to do so for the last 11 years.  He has tried so many medications; some will work for awhile and then quit being effective, then he'd be on something else.  Finally received a blood test in August 09; his IgE level was well over 500.  Finally got approved to take Xolair, however, after only 2 injections in November '09, he broke out into hives and extremely severe itching.  Stopped the Xolair immediately to see if this was causing the hives.  He is also diabetic and was taken off of insulin for a short period of time to see if that may be the cause of the hives or reacting with the Xolair.  It has now been 3 months since his 2nd and last injection of Xolair, and he is still suffering from extreme hives and itching.  Has been to his dermatologist (he also has mild eczema)twice, his regular doctor twice, and an allergist twice.  The one good thing, however, is that he has had no breathing problems at all!  Has not even used any of his other asthma medications, although we worry that eventually his asthma symptoms will return.  So, I'd have to say it has helped his asthma, but the side of effects of the itching is just not tolerable for him, and so far none of the medications are helping with the itching.  Perhaps his problem is tied to the fact that he is diabetic.  His eczema is very mild (was severe when he was a child); only needs an injection once a year to clear it up.

column9: After many other drugs failed to control my moderate asthma, this one changed my life for the first 18 months. I was clear most of the time. column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: dakotabillg, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have had allergies since I was a baby and have had chronic allergic and asthmatic symptoms my entire life.  This is a hands down miracle drug for me.  I'm not cured, I'm not symptom free, but I'm a normal person.  A house with cats doesn't send me into a wheezing fit, I don't break out in hives, dashing past the perfume counter at the drug store, I can actually sit outside for dinner without undue suffering.  I still get some tightness in my chest from ragweed and dogs still make me a little itchy, and my nose runs when someone is cooking potpouri, but I'm just a person with some allergies, not someone who is two steps shy of a bubble.It is a royal pain going for an Allergist appointment every two weeks and the injections sometimes hurt like a horsefly bite, but being able to watch my kids play baseball without having to hide in my climate controlled car would be worth three times the toil.If all of the other medicines seem like they are just the barest mask of relief, seriously consider medicine.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: mrs.claus, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Neutral because I start injections later this week. Several concerns...I have read all of the reviews here and also all the info I was given and on the 'net.  Why are some of you - with heart issues - still taking the drug?  Also, I am going to get an injection once a month - some of you every 2 weeks - I will ask about this.  FYI I started having severe asthma 32 years ago (I am nearly 58) and took steriods until about 12 years ago....then 4 years ago I became a type 1 diabetic and several specialists  have decided it is because of the long steriod use...so be very careful!  I am truly going to give this my all and hope for the best since I need to be able to play with my grandchildren and live my best life possible.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: kshjit, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have given 3 stars as a neutral.  I am just beginning treatment this Friday and I am terrified!  I am in the middle of school and looking to start clinicals at the beginning of the year.  I'm scared!  I know how it is "supposed to work".  The reviews aren't great.  My Ig levels are so far the computer could not read them on 4 occasions in a one month period while hospitalized on all the IV juice.  I have had docs giving me allergy shots and I've told them "you are killing me"  "I can not even get out of bed or think".  They coined me a complainer.  I hope this doesn't happen again. If you suffer like I do then you know the people that look at you and say you are not sick, when you can't shower (only wash your body and not do your hair), how accurate are the tests by whom? Furthermore can anyone hear us out here????  And my favorite-being cussed by old farts because you can walk but parked in handicap! What a joy!  They don't know that I'm trying not to have to be on the news tonight thank you.  It's all about preventative and knowing limitations with that in mind-sorry old farts in wheelchairs - soon to join ya!  Just so happens a bad aid is not made for me right now! I wish the best for you all - I understand the struggle and times of waking up refreshed are few but they are damn good aren't they?

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: deecee43, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have had my 4th shot and I am feeling wonderful.  I was able to control my asthma with allergy shots until 9 years ago.  I had a mild heart attack and was no longer able to receive the shots.  No amount of inhaled steroids could give me much relief.  Two weeks after my first shot the difference was so much so that I've been able to walk without any shortness of breath and can climb hills and stairs without help of an inhaler. My quality of life has improved so much.  I haven't had any side effects so far.  I feel very fortunate that I've been able to get this medicine.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment

column9: I have chronic and severe asthma. Cortisone sprays and prednisone, antibiotics 2-3 x/year.Pets have sent me to hospital in 30-60 minutes. Xolair ends this 85%. Prednisone and sprays cannot replicate the way my lungs open up from xolair.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Have Asthma since moving to Olklahoma. Never had it any other state of residence.  Take my shot every 2 weeks and have had 3 doses.  Experience a weird side effect that seems to be unique.  In about 8 hours after the 3rd injection, I experienced a strong alteration to my sense of smell.  Everything had an acrid, almost waxy rancid smell to it.  Took 25 mg of Benadryl about 3 hours from the onset of the symptom, noticed a small reduction in the intensity and took another 25mg about an hour later.  I continue the 50 mg of Prednisone therepy scheduled for that evening.  Noticed I still had a slight alteration of sense of smell in the am.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: Gracie, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My first few months on xolair my breathing improved however I developed a severe rash on my leg after 4 months.  I never attributed it to the xolair as we had just returned from scuba diving and site seeing in Mexico.  After 6 months, the rash has spread up and around my leg, from my ankle to my knee.  It swells by almost 2 inches as the day goes on and the itching is driving me crazy.  Lately I noticed a lump in the middle of it that was painful at times.  I have been to 7 doctors and today had a surgical biopsy where they went down to the muscle.  The infectious disease doctor believes it may be a reaction to the xolair.  The last couple of weeks my asthma returns at night, first the coughing and them my inhaler.  I have even had to use my nebulizer several times.  I had been so relieved to be off the steroids.  We know steroids are bad - could xolair be any worse?  What are the long term effects of xolair - it hasn't been on the market that long.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have just completed my third shot and have found that I am breathing like a non-asthmatic for the first time in over 20 years. After starting off the year with 4 asthma visits to the ER in one month, my asthma specialist suggested Xolair. I did my research on the drug, its FDA approval trials, web researched how the drug is made and searched the reviews of current users and made my decision. I have been living like a different person for the past three months, feeling almost asthma symptom free. My specialist informed me of the new FDA information on Xolair and I will continue to use the shots until the FDA study is complete. At this point the quality of my life is so improved with Xoliar that I am enjoying a life freerer of the asthma symptoms that have plagued me for the past 20 years.

column9: I was diagnosed with allergic asthmas in my mid 20's. Luckily for me, I only has 1 year of this suffering before I was introduced to Xolair. Now, I feel as if I never had asthma before now as long I continue my inhaled steroid, but if I forget my inhaler, I know I'm ok. During my year before I was on Xolair, if I went on vacation and forgot my inhaled steroids, I would feel it right away, now, when this happens, I don't anymore. Xolair has given me great results. Now, I don't about you guys, but this drug is expensive. I hope someone makes another drug like this soon to drop the price down. I've been on this for 3 years now.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: tootles25018, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: After fifty three years of life, my current doctor gave me an allergy test for the first time in my life, He actually apologized to me.He said I was more allergic to anything than anyone he had ever met except someone that lived in a bubble.  I have had severe asthma for over thirty years ending up in the hospital usually twice a year on IV steroids.  I was using so many medications I had to carry them around in a shoe box and I was in fear of going anywhere without my  portable nebulizer. I have been on the Xolair for a little over a year and I have had only one asthma attack and it was mild( compared to others). Being on disability I have had to fight to keep getting the shots as Medicare does not cover them.  Fortunately at present I am not on Medicare, but fear the day I will be. I hope this company does everything they can to get it approved by Medicare and for anyone that needs it. Although my health has deteriorated  from the constant use of steroids over the last thirty five years, I feel considerable better than I did and know that if I had not been put on the Xolair could likely be dead by now.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: wheezy74, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Xolair is the best Christmas present I will receive this year.  After three years of battling with insurance companies and drug reps, I have finally been given the opportunity to use Xolair and it has changed my life.  In the first 2 weeks of treatment I noticed a remarkable difference.  I look forward to a new year free of steroids, free of moon face, and freedom from having to lug my nebulizer around with me.  What a blessing!

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: lilmcd8777, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: The medication has been a God-send.  Over the past two years I've finally been able to start living my life.  My asthma no longer controls my day; I no longer have to worry about whether or not I'm going to be exposed to something that is going to trigger my asthma.  I actually went hiking in Yellowstone this past fall and didn't one single flare-up.  I no longer take dozens of drugs that only somewhat controlled my asthma.  The ease of use issue isn't related to Genetech or the drug itself...it's related to the stupid (and stupid is a very nice way to put it) pharmaceutical company.  I've had many problems with OptionCare.  Every four weeks they are suppose to automatically send the medication to my doctor's office.  More than once I've gotten there to find out they forgot to send it.  I end up being 1-2 weeks late due to the screw ups.  I've gotten calls asking me to pay outrageous balances that I don't owe, only to find out they have me confused with someone else.  I've also had them incorrectly calculate how much I owe.  When I do have balances, I call within a few days of getting the bill to have the payment handled electronically.  Even after attempting to pay bills in a timely fashion, I get calls and letters threatening to send my bill to a collection agency or small claims court for failing to pay it on time.  I have to keep very accurate records of who I talk to and when and half they time they tell me that the person I talked to wasn't in the correct department and couldn't have handled the payment...so why did they take my payment information and tell me they would take care of this?!?!?  My favorite is when they call me in MAY or JUNE to let me know my insurance had made changes to the payment plan in JANUARY!  Are you kidding me...you just figured this out?!?!?  I'm nearly at the point of stopping the medication because I'm so tired of dealing with the pharmacy.  The hassle I go through on a regular basis just doesn't seem worth it.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: cwk, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This is magic medicine! It took about 5 months to start working for me.  Just about when I was ready to call it quits on the shots, the Xolair did its thing. I was on high dose steroids all the time before and never could get my asthma symptoms under control no matter what combination of medications we tried. My quality of life had really deteriorated. For someone 31 years old, I felt like I had the health of someone who was 80.  Now, my peak flows are consistently higher and even though I do occasionally have symptoms, they are very mild and actually go away after a dose of albuterol instead of lasting for weeks and weeks with little relief.  I really never thought anything would significantly improve things, and that constant asthma was just something I had to accept. But this was the magic bullet. All I had to do was give it time to work.  It truly changed my life.  I never review medications, but this one was worth it.

column1: Allergic Asthma that is Resistant to Treatment
column2: GiGi, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This is my second round with the injections. After one year of injections (2 every 2 weeks) I decided to stop for awhile-went off for about 8 months only to find my symtoms returned and asthma began controlling my life again. My asthma began at age 39. (Currently I receive 3 injections every 2 weeks and am symtom free! The day of the injections I do feel tired so I time my appointments for later in the afternoon.The injections can be painful.  If this occurs, I recommend asking for a different person as every nurse is not talented with injections. I am very pleased with the set-up at my doctor's office. Find the right provider for yourself-it makes a difference with your success. Regarding cost; It is an expensive drug, you have to commit to the time and the affordability issue. BUT you just might get your life back...as I have...Good luck!
